caption: A desire to attend the French Open is one that many share, but acquiring tickets can be a challenge.  Fortunately, reasonably priced tours of Roland-Garros are readily available throughout the year.  While you will sacrifice watching the best tennis players in the world compete, you will gain access to portions of the grounds that are usually strictly off-limits to fans.  The broadcast networks tend to focus on just a few show courts during the tournament, so the ability to roam more broadly provides a tremendous opportunity.  While the tour is guided and you are not permitted to explore without boundaries, this is a truly unique experience.  It includes a visit to the Men‚Äôs Locker Room, and while not diminutive, it serves as a way station for numerous sizable egos and there must be times when cramming them all into this space is a challenge.  If you ‚Äúdon‚Äôt prefer‚Äù the company of one or more players there is absolutely no way that you‚Äôll be able to completely avoid them while utilizing the many features that are available (including a napping room with 3 beds). üò¥  Tracing the players‚Äô steps leading from there to Court Philippe-Chatrier is also an interesting experience.  Although you travel a surprisingly small number of steps, I‚Äôll bet they seem innumerable for the player who has recently been vanquished.  Once we made our way to this site‚Äôs ultimate stage, I was struck by just how cavernous it is.  The seats rise from court level at such a steep angle that it has the feel of a coliseum and I can only imagine how exposed a player can feel in front of a full house.  If it doesn‚Äôt happen to be your day, your flaws are on full display for all to see.  I suppose the ultimate outcome for a tour such as this one is to create an appetite for a visit during tournament play.  If so, then I‚Äôm ‚Äúhangry‚Äù for a big serving of the French Open in 2025!  And that‚Äôs‚Ä¶Henry‚Äôs Take.  #rolandgarros
It‚Äôs the iconic stadium where French open takes place every year. It‚Äôs just mind blowing when you visit. I would highly recommend a guided tour if time permits.

Iconic venue. Lots of amenities available and potable water stations everywhere which was very needed and helpful during the 35¬∞C day of tournament we were there for - definitely a key highlight feature!

I've always wanted to come to Rolland garros, I've been watching the French open since Gustavo Keurten won in the late 90s, early 00s. I know the history, why the area is called Roland Garros, the four musketeers who mean a lot to French tennis. I felt like I knew the place even though I've never been. But now that I've been, words can't express how amazing this place is. I came here during the Olympics and Roland Garros was so busy, the sun was shining, the Nadal statue was gleaming, the masses were in a good mood üòä I soaked up the atmosphere by walking around Roland Garros before entering the Philippe Chatrier court, I managed to find excellent seats in the centre of the court. I was so happy, the stadium is magnificent. It's the perfect place to stage intense battles. I watched two matches, one with Carlos alcaraz, the Spanish were going crazy, the other with iga Swiatek who was supreme in her bronze match. If you're a lover of tennis, you have to come to Roland Garros, you'll enjoy every second being here üòä

Unbelievable experience. Entry into the heart of Rolland Garda with access to player change rooms and media rooms. This is an unbelievable experience for tennis fans. The tour guide was amazing and well knowledged.

I watched wheelchair tennis here at La Stade Roland Garros, site of the French Open grand slam tournament and the premier clay court in the world. For les jeux paralympiques, there are numerous Paris 2024 shops and a large store. The grounds are lively and I would love to return to see the French Open in the future.

I had a chance to be at Roland Garros this year and it was indeed an amazing experience. I spent all day there watching all the matches and enjoying the time as a tennis fan. Plenty of places to eat and drink , lots of boutiques with gifts , big crowds of people and a great atmosphere.

Watching two Olympic tennis matches at the legendary Roland Garros Stadium was an unforgettable experience. It was incredible to see Djokovic win a semifinal match against Musetti, especially witnessing the signature slides on the iconic clay courts. Being in such a historic venue, known for hosting some of the most thrilling moments in tennis, made the experience all the more special.

Our visit to Roland Garros Stadium was a journey filled with unexpected twists, surprising discoveries, and unforgettable moments that left an indelible mark on us. As my wife and I arrived at the stadium's address on 2 Av. Gordon Bennett, 75016 Paris, France, we were initially struck by the charming exterior that resembled a flower shop. Little did we know, this was just the beginning of our unique experience.  Approaching the entrance, we were met with the information that the court's entrance was temporarily closed. Though initially disappointed, this setback turned into an opportunity as we stumbled upon an unlocked door at the back. Eager to explore, we seized the chance and stepped inside the hallowed grounds of Roland Garros Stadium.  The sight that greeted us was nothing short of enchanting. As we walked onto the court, we couldn't help but feel the weight of history beneath our feet. The covered seats seemed to whisper stories of legendary matches and iconic rivalries that had unfolded here. It was a privilege to be in the very space where tennis greats had once competed, where cheers echoed and emotions ran high.  The juxtaposition of our unexpected entry and the monumental significance of the location made our experience all the more meaningful. Standing on the court where historic battles took place, we could almost sense the spirit of competition that had infused the atmosphere. Despite not witnessing a live match, the magic of Roland Garros Stadium enveloped us in a way we hadn't anticipated.  Reflecting on our visit, from mistaking the exterior for a flower shop to stumbling upon the unlocked door that led us onto the court, we were reminded that life's surprises often lead to the most cherished memories. The friendly security guard, the architecture, and the sense of history woven into every corner of the venue added to the richness of our visit.  Taking all aspects into consideration ‚Äî the unexpected journey, the unlocked door, the atmosphere of the court, and the storied history ‚Äî I wholeheartedly bestow a five-star rating upon Roland Garros Stadium. Our experience, though not conventional, was one that we will forever hold close, a testament to the venue's allure and its ability to create lasting memories in even the most unexpected of circumstances.

Everything is just perfect here. The atmosphere is thrilling. We are here with the whole family for the French Open for the first time. The process of purchasing the tickets was overwhelming & rather frustrating. Not only the waiting time but also once you are in the line, there is limitation of the tickets you can get as well as limited time to complete your purchase. Well, you get some experience after done it once. The stadium itself is magical, it worth everything to come. There are three big counts, and many smaller side courts. You need to only get tickets for big ones and you can visit any of the smaller court any time. Night tickets are for one match at the Court Philippe Chatrier that plays at 20:45. You could enter as of 18:30, to watch matches play at side courts or visit their amazing boutiques. Day tickets you can enter as of 10 and stay for the whole day. There are many volunteers whom work here that ensure everything runs smoothly, and keeping the stadium very clean and organized. Love everything about it.

Went to see the King of Clay on his last dance at Roland Garros, say goodbye to the great Rafa Nadal in his theatre.  The grounds are beautiful, lots of vibrant activity, excitement for the tournament and overall a great experience

A legendary sports complex, Roland-Garros Stadium has borne witness to some of the greatest moments in tennis history over the 95 years it has hosted the French Open (such as the classic battle between Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova in the 1985 final, or a 19 year old Rafael Nadal winning the tournament on his first attempt).  Named in memory of French aviator Roland Garros, the venue is spread over 12 hectares and has 18 clay courts, including the Simonne Mathieu and Suzanne Lenglen Courts (which will host tennis events at Paris 2024) and the Philippe Chatrier Court (boxing and tennis).

Really nice venue and the atmosphere is great.  It's like being in Disney world but about everything related to tennis üéæ. There are plenty of options to eat inside, but the price is a little bit expensive. Bring your food from outside.

Loved this place. A great stadium for tennis lovers. We took a tour but by mistake it happened to be in french. The guide was really nice to translate the highlights of the tour in english and made our day. A must visit place for tennis fans.

We had a wonderful tour of this iconic stadium just a couple days after Nadal officially announced his retirement. It was amazing to see behind the scenes in this place where they practically worship him. His statue is pretty cool. We were also there on the first day the museum was open to the public, and it is a nice addition to the facilities.
Didn't get to see any tennis, but it's a great stadium. All the courts are close, so you could literally run from match to match.

I went for a guided visit and I can say it is a mandatory stop in Paris if you are a tennis fan. The tour guide feeds you with a history class on how it all began, the preparation and the backstage of the tournament and provides you access to very exclusive areas. The tour is all around the Philippe-Chatrier court and unfortunately we do not get to step on the clay. It is all very exciting and the 90 minutes feel too short given all there is visit and how much we want to see and learn.

This is a magic experience for all tennis lovers. One of the best tournaments of the season and one of the best facilities of the tennis tour.  I have been four times to Roland Garros and it‚Äôs always a pleasure. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you attend the qualies, first rounds, final rounds or just watch the games through the big screens outside, there is always a great atmosphere.  The stadiums Philip Chatrier and Suzanne Lenglen are the main attractions, but I would also recommend to watch the matches of the other courts, so you are closer to the players and the game.  The negative points are the crazy prices of the food and drinks and the confusion and long waiting time when entering, leaving or trying to go into a small court.

Visited during the opening week of the French Open to see qualifyings. Signage to the stadium is quite poor, and it's easy to get lost finding the correct gate.  The event space itself is massive, with lots of stores and live performances and activities. However, lots of these were closed for opening week. Tennis was excellent, despite Nadal pulling out last minute. Make sure to get the App to find out what games are playing when, and certain courts have quite the line up (14).  Water fountains are provided, but merch inside will be a bit steep.

I booked the 90 minute tour organized throughout the week to know more about the RG History and dare I say that I wasn't disappointed. The tour guide explained the story & the process of how they came up with the RG name, we visited philipe chatrier court from the top and from the bottom and the sight of it when it's empty was alone breathtaking as it's been always my dream to visit RG let alone when you watch an actual match!!, learned about the history of the stadium, seen the lockers, trophies(original) room, press room, and the famous Rafa iron statue. The tour ended with a visit to the boutique where we can buy shirts, caps, balls, rackets, jackets and some souvenirs like key chains and magnets, and if you take part in the tour, you get 10% discount on your purchases from the boutique(souvenir shop) I asked about Rafa merch, I was told by the employee that it's only available during the time of the tournament itself, so only 3 weeks a year Had an absolute blast and by far was one of my best experiences, looking forward to coming here again but this time during the RG tournament itself. The Tour is conducted in 2 languages, Both French and English and booking via website a few days in advance is essential to ensure the right time and language for visitors.

Great place, really clean and staff is friendly. The major downside is that if you want to buy a beer there is only a small amount of stores that's sells it. Also you need to wait for a break in order to leave or come back to your seat.

We splurged and got the Premium Passion package which included a tour of the grounds and a meeting with Henri Leconte. Plenty of finger foods and beverages were offered.  The main shopping area was very busy in the morning, so get your souvenir items later in the day. The Philippe Chatrier Stadium was just about the right size, not huge like the US Open, and not quite as intimate as Wimbledon‚Äôs Centre Court.
Incredible historic grand slam venue. The facilities are top notch, service and team are excellent. Seats and arenas are perfect. Watched Alcaraz first round match and it was a spectacle!
Beautiful amazing stadium! Such an iconic place to be!

We had a great experience watching live French open2019 matches.  The information about matches had been well laid and there were volunteers to help. You are allowed to carry picnic however there were few restaurants or food kiosks inside too. Important tip, buggies/ prams, luggage,     more than 500ml of water bottle,  big backpacks are not allowed to be taken in the stadium. They provide the cloak room which is located outside of the stadium(nearly 500mtrs) to deposit your stuff securely and reclaim it after your stadium visit.  Inside the stadium there was some gaming space which had Play station tennis games or small courts to play real tennis,  that kids and adults enjoyed alike.   Also there were musicians spread across the stadium that made the experience outside the courts lively. Public utilities like toilets were clean and available close to the courts. For drinking water only option was to buy bottles. Overall we had a great experience. Only trouble was that since pram was not allowed inside we had to carry our toddler all around and watch matches turn wise :p

Unfortunately the main stadium was closed when I got there and only people with prior reservations could gain access but it was definitely an interesting view. I also explored the accessory store just beside it and there I found really good quality collections of items which would definitely excite any tennis enthusiast. I‚Äôll definitely recommend!üëçüèæ

Good experience. Great day out with friends but just don‚Äôt wear high heels as there‚Äôs a lot of walking to do to get from one court to another and from the restaurant and toilets. Easier to take a taxi there instead of driving as parking can be difficult. Don‚Äôt forget to bring your ID that matches the name on the ticket.

I really had a great time watching an epic game of the semi-final and like realizing my dream. It is recommended to arrive here earlier before the game start because there are many securities before entering. Be careful of what is not allowed to bring into the stadium, and it is better to prepare your own water and food when watching the game because it sells much higher inside the area. There are big screens in the area so people watch the games before the screen. Also shops and cafe for people to chill, and the facilities are really nice and considerate of people. A tennis fan will definitely enjoy the games and the atmosphere of Roland Garros.
Great Place. Very well organized, no stress, great ambiance. You really feel good watching the matches.
Roland Garros grounds are absolutely brilliant. The atmosphere is unique, and you can find iconic places and figures in every corner. Well worth the visit!
If you love tennis you have to go- the tour is telling you all you want to know...and more.Can you imagine coming out of the tunnel like the players? Unbelievable

Absolutely incredible! Stade Roland Garros is a beautifully elegant tennis venue, with modern and old fashioned decor and lots of greenery. The Philippe Chatrier court gives a fantastic atmosphere and the access to the ground courts is also available and the atmosphere is extremely partisan. I would also particularly recommend Court Simone Mathieu, set in the middle of a greenhouse and under the night sky, the atmosphere is truly one of a kind. In addition, late in the evening, Court Suzanne Lenglen and Simone Mathieu can be free access giving bonus tennis for free! Overall, the experience is truly memorable (yes, expensive) but totally worth the price!
Paris, France, 2024 It was the final in tennis üéæ The winner was Netherlands Second England 3rd South Africa
Great experience on all the tennis courts and all over the village!

Best time of my life being here. As a tennis fan this is the place you want to be. The complex us beautiful with restaurants , shops and guided plan laid everywhere. If you have tickets to the main stadium Philippe Chatrier or Suzanne Lenglen you can visit all the side courts for here. Even if you cannot afford the big court tickets you can get a daily pass for few bucks and you can enter all the side courts and watch any match .the feel of being in d midst of french open is something else. I had the good luck to watch Djokovic, Theim , sharapova in the Philippe Chatrier stadium. Huge court and you can view perfectly where you are seated. Also i watched martina hingis & Leander paes upclose in one of the side courts. Great memories. Must visit .
Had a good day here, Q's for everything so bring your own food and drinks but overall a great experience, will be back again
Was only able to go to the opening day but there was so much to see and do! They have a lot of food and beverage stalls, and during off season offer stadium tours too

The tour is very informative with the guide giving us a background on history and a backstage tour to the locker rooms etc. the only problem is the tour is only available in French. Please note: There are no lavatories for the public/elderly to access
